video.title: Mafia: The Old Country | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
So, I learned something new this week 
thanks to Mafia: The Old Country:

the original name of the Sicilian Mafia, Cosa 
Nostra, translates literally to &quot;Our Thing.&quot;

And I kind of love that. All those dudes getting 
together in their sheds and basements to compare

their things. I picture them going back up 
to their wives. &quot;Sorry I&#39;m late for dinner,

darling. All the lads had to pull out their 
things, and it took quite a while to get through

them all. And today was particularly exhausting 
&#39;cause we had to whack off a bunch of guys. Now,

hold still while I slap you about a bit in case 
Martin Scorsese&#39;s watching.&quot; So, Mafia 1 set in

the &#39;30s, Mafia 2 in the &#39;40s and &#39;50s, Mafia 
3 in the &#39;60s, and now the new Mafia game is,

logically, set in 1900. Man, what the fuck kind 
of Fibonacci sequence is this? I was looking

forward to one set in the &#39;90s where we go around 
whacking off dudes listening to Ace of Base, but

never mind. We play as Enzo, a young man enslaved 
in a Sicilian sulfur mine run by gangsters that

everyone keeps talking about like he&#39;s a skinny, 
helpless little slave child even though he is very

obviously a large, burly man. What&#39;s with that? 
This used to only happen with live action stuff

&#39;cause no one wants child actors at the Craft 
Services table eating all the Wagon Wheels.

Anyway, Enzo escapes from the mine using 
his powers of obviously being a large,

burly man and gets chased to a vineyard owned by 
a rival, less evil crime family who take him in

as a stable boy and let him live in the outside 
toilet basically just to piss off the more evil

crime family, and soon, Enzo becomes part of the 
community. And just as he&#39;s settling in, a hot

lady stops at the door to the outside toilet and 
starts giving him the eye. And in that moment, I

correctly predicted the entire course of the plot, 
down to every significant development. Obviously,

this girl is the daughter of the stern, overly 
protective mob boss who is Enzo&#39;s new father

figure, and she feels trapped and oppressed and 
red hot to get bent over the hitching rail and is

looking at this foul-smelling, sulfur-encrusted, 
large, burly man and thinking this is exactly the

kind of hot piece of crumpet that&#39;ll piss my dad 
off. And then Enzo&#39;s gonna gradually rise in the

ranks thanks to his large, burly man skills until 
he&#39;s one of the most trusted soldiers; there&#39;ll be

the point where everything&#39;s going really well and 
Enzo&#39;s thinking, &quot;Wow, turns out crime DOES pay.&quot;

And then everything will go to shit. 
The forbidden love affair is exposed;

Enzo is disgraced and disillusioned and has to 
knife fight basically every character with a

name. In brief, it&#39;s all very obvious. And 
you know what else is obvious? The large,

seamless open world. Although apparently 
the game itself doesn&#39;t think so. &quot;Wow,

that certainly is an open world you&#39;ve got there,&quot; 
I cried out loud. &quot;Can&#39;t wait to explore it for

collectibles and side content.&quot; &quot;What?&quot; went the 
game. &quot;What open world? What on earth are you

talking about? Just keep following this extremely 
linear series of plot points.&quot; I can&#39;t believe

this has happened again. Yet another open world 
with bugger all purpose except to force you to

commute across the map between story objectives. 
Although Mafia 2 was similar, if memory serves.

And in contrast to MindsEye, there is at least 
a convenient &quot;skip travel&quot; button that will warp

you straight to the next important bit. But 
in that case, why does the game have an open

world in the first place? &quot;Our new all-in-one 
kitchen blender comes free with a garbage sack

and a litter picker to help you clear up all 
the bits of debris it leaves behind.&quot; &quot;Well,

thanks, but I&#39;d prefer to just have a kitchen 
blender that doesn&#39;t spontaneously explode.&quot;

There are times when you can go off the 
plotted route and explore the open world,

but the moment you leave the current intended 
story area, all the life and chattering NPCs

disappear and you&#39;re left exploring deserted 
backroads like you went off script on the

Truman Show. So, if I can&#39;t call it an open world 
game—I mean, the Steam tags don&#39;t—what else could

it be? A shooter? A stealth game? There&#39;s 
certainly shooting and stealthing in it,

much in the way there&#39;s an open world in it, but 
I wouldn&#39;t call either the core system. No, let&#39;s

just call it by the thing you&#39;ll be mostly doing. 
Ergo, Mafia: The Old Country is a &quot;walk slowly

behind NPCs, waiting for them to finish gabbing 
off about shit you don&#39;t care about&quot; &#39;em up. Oh,

joy. I do so love walk-and-talk sequences. They 
make me nostalgic for when my mother needed me out

of the way and would keep me amused by letting me 
listen to audiobooks while riding back and forth

on airport travelators all afternoon. It&#39;s fine 
to be primarily story focused if that&#39;s what you

want to be, but it might help if your story wasn&#39;t 
utterly predictable and mawkishly melodramatic.

So, most of the chapters of the game consist 
of some establishing walk and talk, a long ride

through the country, and eventually, a token 
gameplay bit. Sometimes, it&#39;ll be cover-based

shooting in the classic &quot;press A to glue yourself 
to a chest-high wall while enemies pop up and down

like Conrad Poohs and his dancing teeth&quot; style. 
Or it&#39;ll be a stealth mission, which as usual

entails crouch-walking behind patrolling guards; 
distracting them with thrown objects; picking

them off with the odd surprise chiropractic neck 
therapy of death. Which is functional enough—dare

I say fun—but it felt like after every single 
fucking successful stealth mission, the game would

go, &quot;Nice job getting no alerts, but, oh, this 
is awkward; we kind of had an exciting shootout

lined up for the next bit. Sooo... Oh no! You get 
spotted in a cutscene! Clumsy you! Shoot all the

dudes.&quot; This is part of the reason I struggled 
to relate to the main character, I suppose,

because he never fucking listened to me. Enzo, 
mate, what on Earth was the fucking point of me

working so hard to get you all the way through 
the opera house to the royal box without being

spotted even once if you&#39;re then gonna stab the 
dude and push him off the balcony into the crowd?

And then stand there like a fucking nonplussed 
circus seal as a spotlight gets trained on you?

Remember how you didn&#39;t listen to me about 
eight hours ago when the boss&#39;s daughter was

eyeing your bum cheeks and I said, &quot;Don&#39;t you 
fucking dare. You&#39;ve got a good thing going;

pile up a load of grapes and discarded meat 
scraps into the shape of a woman if you need a

wet dick THAT badly. You&#39;re wishing you did that 
now, aren&#39;t ya? And while we&#39;re on the subject,

next time someone challenges you to a knife 
fight, listen to me for once and just shoot

them in the fucking head.&quot; I wasn&#39;t kidding 
earlier. Every single boss fight with a named

character in this game is an inescapable knife 
fight sequence, and they&#39;re all pretty much

identical. Press parry if they attack. Press 
dodge if they do super glowing attack. Press super

glowing attack if they block. It&#39;s like if fucking 
Dragon&#39;s Lair was set in Glasgow. In summary,

switch to red background, Mafia: The Old Country 
is even more aptly named than even it realizes

because it certainly does get old very fast. It&#39;s 
old hat. Old news. Old ideas and old mechanics

making the same old mistakes. Take it behind 
the old woodshed and treat it like Old Yeller.
